# Joining data frames

---

## Joining data frames

```
something_join(x, y)
```

- `left_join()`: all rows from x
- `right_join()`: all rows from y
- `full_join()`: all rows from both x and y
- `semi_join()`: all rows from x where there are matching values in y, keeping just columns from x
- `inner_join()`: all rows from x where there are matching values in y, return 
all combination of multiple matches in the case of multiple matches
- `anti_join()`: return all rows from x where there are not matching values in y, never duplicate rows of x
- ...

# Data joins in practice

---

## Students

- Have:
  - Enrolment: official university enrolment records
  - Survey: Student provided info missing students who never filled it out and including students who filled it out but dropped the class
- Want: Survey info for all enrolled in class 

.pull-left[
```{r message = FALSE}
enrolment <- read_csv("data/student-enrolment.csv")
enrolment
```
]
.pull-right[
```{r message = FALSE}
survey <- read_csv("data/student-survey.csv")
survey
```
]

---

## Students

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[In class]
```{r}
enrolment %>% 
  left_join(survey) #<<
```
]

.panel[.panel-name[Survey missing]
```{r}
enrolment %>% 
  anti_join(survey) #<<
```
]

.panel[.panel-name[Dropped]
```{r}
survey %>% 
  anti_join(enrolment) #<<
```
]

]

---

## Sales

- Have:
  - Sales data: One row per customer per item, listing purchases they made
  - Price data: One row per item in the store, listing their prices
- Want: Total revenue

.pull-left[
```{r message = FALSE}
sales <- read_csv("data/sales.csv")
sales
```
]
.pull-right[
```{r message = FALSE}
prices <- read_csv("data/prices.csv")
prices
```
]

---

## Sales

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Total revenue]
.pull-left[
```{r}
sales %>% 
  left_join(prices) #<<
```
]
.pull-right[
```{r}
sales %>% 
  left_join(prices) %>%
  summarise(total_revenue = sum(price)) #<<
```
]
]

.panel[.panel-name[Revenue per customer]

.pull-left[
```{r}
sales %>% 
  left_join(prices)
```
]
.pull-right[
```{r}
sales %>% 
  left_join(prices) %>%
  group_by(customer_id) %>% #<<
  summarise(total_revenue = sum(price))
```
]

]

]
